welcome to black hat briefings 2001 held July 11th through the 12th in Las Vegas Nevada this is videotape number 34
solving Network Mysteries [Music]
hello think we got a late start I just want to point out my hat everyone like my hat I I do that
myself uh my name's Dan Van Bellin I work at Sr I
uh going to give a quick talk on what I call about solving Network Mysteries part of um part of my motivation for
this talk is I've been doing the Contracting Consulting thing for about 10 years now and being a consultant I
get the opportunity to go out to see different networks different network environments and we see a lot of um a
lot of strange stuff on the networks we go and see uh I've been collecting different stories and I've been trying
to compile them what I'm trying to do is just share some of the stories I have with you and try to build a case for
including audit and monitoring as part of your security program so so just want to start with a quick background about
um just who I am I work for a company called s where a Government Contracting Consulting Group uh I work in the
engineering side in their information insurance department and I do things like penetration testing training
readiness reviews incident response and uh security assessments and in my past
life I've done similar things for different companies just to start my talk off I'd
start with a little quiz um just to ask some questions these are pretty basic questions um but when we go
out and do our different assessments you'd be surprised at how many of the security officers and administrators
can't answer these these simple questions so how many people here can answer some of these questions how many
people know what's happening on your network any anyone know what their users are doing if uh users are complying with
policy how many people here have security policies or work in organiz ation with security policies how many
people are compliant with those policies okay many of my friends in the security Community uh they only wear
their security hat when they're getting paid to wear their hat otherwise they fall into the user category and they may
not be um always compliant how many uh how users know if
your internal or external Communications are affecting your posture anyone picked up this
magazine it's free the cover talks about the silent thread of outbound email uh
decent article it talks just about what information is sensitive within your organization and what some of the things
you can do to help protect yourself from users or employees sending out information that you may not want being
sent out with your name attached to it um how many people know if if you can
detect Anonymous behavior on your network to be able to detect Anonymous Behavior you need to be know what your
normal behavior looks like and then you can tell what's anomalous and then um
Network diagrams just having a network wire diagram showing your different system set up you don't always know what information is being set between those
two systems so uh with this talk I'm going to talk again about some examples of um
some experiences I've had with different engagements where if people had audit and monitoring as part of their program
they could have been um could have been avoided and then with each of the examples I'm going to talk about some of the techniques and
recommendations um that came out of the engagements and then I'll hit on some benefits and uh and various
recommendations for including audit and monitoring in your program uh the various examples I'm
going to talk about um they're all from my personal experience and they're all pretty timely with the exception of one
they've all happened within the last year one's about a year and a half old by now and I'll probably need to take
that one out um I've given this talk for for a while now I keep I try to update it with some of the more current stories
although some of them keep happening over and over and over again so the the first
one is uh with a distributed denial of service agent Discovery this happened
back in January of last year right before the big attacks on eBay and CNN uh this happened with a company that
was an Enterprise Network solution company I point that out just because it was a company that had some pretty
technical Savvy people um they had a firewall they had a firewall policy it happened to allow DNS traffic they had
their main internet point of presence in Colorado that's where they were managed and then they had DNS servers in
Colorado but they also had them in the local Regional Offices here here's a very high level of the network um I just
like to jump down and point to things but I'm not going to be able to do that uh anyway you can see there was
internet poter presence they had a uh the main pop in Colorado they had a firewall primary and secondary DNS
servers and then in all the uh Regional Offices they had the local DNS uh what happened in this case is one of
the Regional Offices was going through some equipment upgrades and rewiring and when they're plugging their equipment
black back in they did some testing and they noticed some unusual traffic and the local Tech was uh super paranoid
thought they'd been hacked so they called us up to come um help take a look
and what we found was that the unusual traffic that was appearing on the firewall and other places um was in IP
address ranges that were reserved this company had a Class B IP P space and in the third octet they used numbers from
one to 100 everything from 100 and up was reserved they weren't supposed to be using it what they found was IP numbers
floating around their Network in this in this reserve space so um something wasn't right so we went out we um looked
on the network and we wanted to get a better feel for where this traffic was coming from so we put some various Network sniffers on the network and what
we noticed um what we noticed was we were able to zero in
in on these IP addresses that were reserved and we noticed they were all kind of coming to and from this DNS
server um so we were able to focus our attention down to that U to that server
and we noticed that uh by going through the logs that it was running a vulnerable uh version of bind um there's
a reason why DNS and bind is always in the top 10 s's greatest vulnerabilities
and this is one of those reasons uh this this one vulnerable version allowed the
attackers to um get root remotely so these attackers came in through the firewall to allow DNS to this local
server they uh they rooted the Box they owned it and then they exploited some other relationships throughout the uh
throughout the network we also able look back at some of the firewall logs and notice that
there's a lot of traffic coming in on Port 53 um that traffic was coming not to the primary and secondary servers but
it was going to the local DNS server in the regional office if that was the firewall was being reviewed regularly
that would have been picked up um a lot sooner so in this example what we did
nothing um nothing super technical but what we what we did was just some uh traffic analysis on that usual unusual
traffic zeroed in on that looked through some of the firewall logs and then the logs on the DNS server and the operating
system and the Lessons Learned were were pretty straightforward as well um but we
found out that the firewall logs weren't being reviewed found out that the DNS server operating system and the
application the logs weren't being reviewed there as well IP spoofing wasn't being monitored and what I mean
by that is the uh the IP addresses in that Reserve uh space weren't being monitored for those IPS shouldn't be on
the network it would have been pretty simple to put up some filters some other monitors to watch for IPs in that range
and that wasn't happening um and not just for security but for uh troubleshooting or other
misconfigurations and then Integrity checking wasn't being performed on their servers either the recommend
flow from those lessons learn basically you know they need to perform some log review of their network service systems
your DNS mail web firewall that has to be done it's not always So Glamorous but you can automate that you can also
Outsource it there are companies out there like counterpane um that will monitor those logs for
you comp like like counter panes one there's several of them but counter pan particular will put sensors out on your
network feed those logs into Those sensors and then send them out over VPN to their secure Operation Center or
their sock there they have analysts watching those logs 24 by7 um when they see anomalous Behavior or unusual
activities they'll report back to you um the other recommendations were to
put up some type of monitoring um software for the network traffic uh again filter out those unusual IPS they
shouldn't be on the network so you can filter those out you're also put some protocol analyzers up if they had been
watching just for DNS traffic and saw those huge jumps um that could have tipped them off a lot lot
sooner and then lastly use some type of Integrity checking trip wire is very popular there's other profile Checkers
out there these are tools that will take an image of the system after you've configured it take that picture in it's
gold stage then you periodically go back take another image and then you compare it if there's any differences then um
there needs to be some type of explanation or someone has some splaining to do
um my next example with with uh harassing emails this is a case where
with an employee within an organization was receiving some harassing emails and they had suspected that um it was coming
from with someone from internally within the organization the emails were coming from outside from a uh anonymous source
hotmail.com anyone can go out and get a hot mail account um these were coming in to
someone on the inside and they were um happening frequently that this company didn't necessar want to prosecute the
person that um was doing this but they wanted to find out who it was and they wanted it to stop so they what they wanted to do is kind of test their
hypothesis that this mail was originating from inside the network um so they called us in to help
them out and what we did was we um we we collected some Network traffic I'm using
a packet sniffer we collected traffic for a couple days and then we had a huge collection of of traffic um we then went
through traffic and we searched for um mail going to and from hotmail.com and
then we were focused in on an IP address um where it was coming from and we were
really looking for some CGI postings to see if we had some proof that they were coming from inside the
network um the next screen I'm going to show you from a tool called net net4 by a company called Network forensics um
this is a this tool I use it just for illustrative purposes because it makes it easier for me to show um what we're
searching for the the net 4 tool is basically a packet sniffer that will collect packet on your network it then
reconstructs the packets into a uh into sessions those sessions are then loaded into a database um and then there's a a
gooy front end a web browser front end to that database so you can query it um I was trying to do something else with
just TCP dump and some regular uh string editors like grep but the screen got
real ugly and the presentation um for PowerPoint just wasn't working so um that's why I'm using this nice gooey so
we had this packet capture we collected traffic for a couple days we had a couple gigabytes of data we went through
we entered in our string looking for traffic going to and from hotmail.com um what came back I I I've
changed the names to protect the uh the guilty um really should be my mother-in-law to know
um you see traffic coming in from Dan z00 Van hotmail.com Dan z00 van is our
uh is the person attacking or sending out these harassing emails or harasser um and then our victim is Dan at
net4.com and what this tool what the search came back was it came back with one email session and I can um the tool
allowed me to drill down to show me more and more detail about these sessions so if I drill down the first time it came up and it showed me the subject a little
bit more information about that that session um subject came up with your mama then I can drill down again to show
me the content of that email and um it came out again this is the
the content of that email that was being sent or being received and you see it's coming from Dan Reser van our harasser
to Dan net4.com and there's a bunch of insults um to to your mama and I tried
to mask out some of the more funny I mean the more offensive insults
um there used to be a tool out there called up yours I'm familiar with it but you could send out insults like this um
with that tool anyway so um once once we found this email we knew that we had this
harassing email within our packet capture so our next step was to go back and see if we could find um the mail
originating from within the company actually being sent out before it was
received so we need to do um a search uh on some unique string and the string we
used was CGI bin Hotmail which is what you would see in your url locator um
window when you're posting emails through Hotmail um a lot of times what we had here was some just really just
raw packets with IP numbers so we didn't have all the IP numbers resolved into
domain names so this is why we had to use um a different string um there are utilities out there that when you
capture your packets it will go through and resolve all those IP numbers into domain names to make your searching easier uh but we had several gigabytes
worth of data so it was take a long time to go out and do that resolving so uh we use this IDE this way instead so by
searching on that string we we were able to come back and find the IP address attached with that Str string and that IP address belongs to hotmail.com one of
their one of their servers um we then came back did more
searching on that IP and came back with all the sessions going out to that that IP address to hotmail.com and I masked
out the uh um the original IP address
what it's showing is these are all the sessions from some internal um IP the one I've mastered out going out to
hotmail.com posting emails so we then went through and drilled down on these sessions and what came out is
um uh this is one of the postings going out there I wish I could Point um on the
bottom line kind of halfway one third of the way over you see a login with the
user ID of Dan 0000 van um so now we're seeing that our harassing harass
harasser ID is being is being logging in to the Hotmail server from within our
organization if I kept rolling down on these sessions we'd actually see the contents of those um insults being
posted up to hot mail and then being sent down so from this we were able to grab the IP of of our harasser and we
were able to confront the user and um the situation stopped and it was actually um resolved um pretty
painlessly in this situation the organization didn't want to press charges it never went to litigation so
we were able to go in and do this type of analysis if someone did want to press charges or take legal action uh we would
have followed some different procedures including getting some permits um and having law enforcement
involved the recommendations that came out of this for this organization was to implement an email policy um this was a
company that was a government contractor that supported the intelligence community so they had some sensitive
information on their network not classify but it was sensitive they they realized they needed to have better control of what information was leaving
their Network so we um recommend they put an email policy in that restricted um
Communications mostly email only going through the production email source that means they couldn't pop out to their ISP
or use IMAP or use AOL or use Hotmail they only they wanted to S an email they had to go through the production email
server and when they did that there was some content filtering that would go through and and and monitor what type of
content was being out being sent out through
email my next example is U is kind of a compilation of of situations where we I
go out and we do a lot of we call um security assessments where we go out and we um assess the security profile of a
network and what we always find you know we go out we run some tools like network discovery tools um some um service
service Discovery tools and we'll come back with a report and we'll find a lot of um we'll come back with a report of
like 400 Pages or something and we'll give them to the administrator saying here's what we found we found all these web servers we found these FTP servers
that weren't configured properly and a lot of times the security officers and the administr kind of scratch their head and say well these aren't our boxes and
well they are yours because they're on your on your network um but they didn't even know about it so this is really
it's not uncommon to have users go out and install a new um a new service on their desktop um I've even seen users
install web servers on their desktop that are allowed through the internet and they're hosting up you know family pictures or something else
um I hear a lot of stories now about I I think we've all heard stories now about the wireless networks how you can drive
up and down um in Silicon Valley and get an 80211 connection just by driving
around um a lot of those networks are probably users putting in access points without
the administrators knowing about it um we also see a lot of cases where
um like for example an Engineering Group will have an FTP Service that they needed to transfer files around um
between the Engineering Group um so they went to it an IT setup an FTP server
form and left of the admin functions to the engineers um the requirements then changed for that Engineering Group to
transfer files to their customers the server then moved out to the DMZ these engineers then wanted to um share files
with you know customers and other contractors they didn't want to have user accounts so they left Anonymous
access and they wanted them the post files so they had right access turned on meanwhile the admins don't know this um
we come into our audit and we find that hey you have not only anous FTP access but you have right access enabled and
you're also hosting about 20 GB worth of Wares um it happens so really when we go
out and we and we do our assessments we're running some pretty basic tools when we start off um we're running some
network discovery tools like fping doing some Port scanning like nmap we um and we run these tools to kind of get an
understanding of the network learn about it um kind of increase our knowledge about the network before we look for
vulnerabilities um these are type of tools that can be automated that administrators and security officers can run on a regular basis this
is what's going to help you learn about your network what's on your network what users are doing running these type of
tools will help you get that knowledge um there are commercial Solutions out there that will help you do this and I'm
going to show you a couple examples of one um called netf Fox again I like the goey and the the concept is really
simple basically you go out do some network discovery find out what's on your network um keep a record of that
and continue to do this when you come back you find a node on your network that doesn't belong there it will flag you um I like netfox I think it's pretty
cool it makes a database of what should be on your network then you can put more information in there like the MAC address usernames phone
numbers um again taking it a step further you can set up a policy you know what type of traffic you want or
Services you want on your network in this case um the the rule set up I you can see that in the back but it's set up
to say well we allow tet traffic and web traffic on our Network um it goes out and does a poll
when it comes back and finds Well if flags and saying well I found those services but I also found five more and
these five don't belong on my network yeah a very simple concept um and
enables you to learn more about about your network so um really recommendations in in this situation is
you need to have a network security policy to help you um set your Baseline and know what to monitor for and then
you need to educate your users to let them know what they're doing when they install a wireless access point or
enable right access on the FTP server um they you have to educate your users to let them know that that's not always the
best thing to do and then Implement some consistent procedures or basically automation um do these things
consistently so you can um enforce your
policy my my last example is with a um system administrators um sometimes we
find administrators that are trying to um manage their Network as best they can
they also do some Remote Management and often that Remote Management is done over unsecure channels that they don't
um they don't realize that that's bad and um in this case is with a um with a
government agency that had outsourced it CIS admin functions This Is Not Unusual in in the
government um with this case we're concerned with a controlled application
Network um with a real strict security perimeter um really tight security
around this application they uh they had a firewall and it only allowed database traffic and email traffic just just the
traffic you needed for that application and they had someone monitoring the firewalls they were um they were taking
things seriously they had a routine audit um where audits came in and when they were interviewing um the security
officers they um security officers felt that there was some of this remote Administration going on but they
couldn't prove it they weren't they weren't able to get in there and prove that this was happening so as part of
the the audit they asked us to uh see what we could find out and what we found out was yeah that administrators were
trying to monitor the status of the network remotely they were um they were setting up a batch job that kicked off
every night that um did a quick you know health check of the systems and they sent those results back back home in
clear text this is a quick example um this is
just some of the information that was in there but it comes back with um host name Network domain information it'll
come back with users on the system um it would come back with IP numbers Network information then Services
running this information is to an attacker is is is what you what you're
looking for and the first step in an assessment or pen testing or or whatever you're doing to your victim is um
information gathering you're trying to build a profile of your of your of your victim this is the type of information
you're looking for you're looking for the network domain information that you can go back and try other hosts within
that domain um you're looking for users that you can go back and brute for those accounts you're looking for Network
information that you can uh get subnets or try enumerate other other nodes on that Network and then Services you want
to know what servic are running you want to go back and consult your vulnerability database um you either they running HTTP or or inet you can go
back to see um if you got anything in your in your bag of tricks no so given that the um the
strict security around this application this type of information was just not allowed um to be be sent out so
um the way we discovered it is we we went back and looked at some of the firewall logs again someone was monitoring the firewall but they were
really looking just for unsuccessful attempts so we could go back and look at the firewall logs and determine that yeah mail was being sent out um and all
the all the email was internal within the organization with the exception of three accounts being sent out to the
three system administrators so we could Zone in real quick that um there was some external traffic happening but we
couldn't see what was what was actually in those emails so by doing some Network traffic analysis going back to our
friendly sniffers we were able to capture some traffic and drill down to the content of those emails and that's how we captured what was
involved um the Lessons Learned for this case were the administrators needed some security awareness training they thought
they were doing a good thing they were trying to keep their Network up 24 by S um they didn't realize the the risk they
were giving now to that environment um there was also no official remote Administration procedures in place again
this this network had to be up 24 by7 but there weren't any procedures to help help do that as well as adequate tools
um to support those requirements the recommendations were
you know straightforward to implement an appropriate um remote admin solution and then do uh conduct constant admin
training and it's important to do this constantly because you'll find administrators change hands a lot throughout the course of a of a contract
um companies of often support multiple clients with there's this admin um team and often there's you know two or three
real Superstars will go in and get the thing stood up and then they'll phase out um so it's important to keep the uh
the training constant it's also important to keep it kind of tailored to that environment so what might be appropriate in one Environ may may not
be appropriate in another that's all my uh all my stories
the what I've been trying to do is build a case for audit and monitoring why why you need to do that as part of your security program and I broke some goals
if you want to try to implement audit and monitoring in your program I broke the goals down to protect um detect and
then analyze and recover and um audit monitoring isn't really what you would think of in terms of protection you
typically that's your firewalls your vpns your ids's but um what audit and monitoring will give you is that
feedback loop we'll give you that Loop feedback into those systems to help make sure they're configured appropriately
and make them better um but in terms of protection it it will help act as a deterrent if users know they're being
held accountable and monitoring for their actions they're less likely to do something wrong I had a friend that was assist
admin um that put put a firewall a couple years ago and when he was going
through some of the logs he NOS there's a lot of traffic going out to adult sites um a whole lot so they set up a
policy saying we're going to start monitoring this for this this is not allowed and uh traffic starts to die
down a little bit so that wasn't good enough so what he did which was kind of neat is he posted a list of the top 10
sites that people were going to then he posted the top 10 users on the network and people kind of Drew their own
conclusions and then uh the adult traffic sites um started dropping off so his bandwith went up way up way
up um in terms of detection this is what audit monitoring really helps you do it helps you um really as a goal you really
want to give analysis of all your data um with detection you want to be able to passively collect information off your
network and you also want to be able to actively scan for services or nodes um
and then under analyze and recover you want to be able to have a forensic level analysis um you want to be able to
answer questions to who what where when how um why is not there we never we never know why but the rest of them you
want to be able to know you want to be able to do full damage control um you want to be able to get logs from your
network systems applications um and if you can get them all to a centralized information source so you don't have to
go out and pull individual systems that's um that's that's key some some of the enablers I'll touch
on these are are your logs you know logs are are really where you find your Footprints or your uh or your
fingerprints um Network you know packet sniffers or or intrusion detection systems help gives you a better look at
that and then to help you with your analysis with all this information you know databases or or scripts automations
are going to help you enable audit monitoring um with logs again logs are
where you find um find your Footprints um they're your number one source of information often often but when we go
out to do our engagements often we find that they haven't been enabled they were never turned on or or they're not there
anymore the the the the log spool space is so small that they keep getting overwritten and the information we're
looking for isn't there um often the Integrity of the logs is questionable if a host has been compromised um you know
you really can't trust the logs as much as you'd like to so having uh an external logging source is is important
um but the most important thing is making sure someone reads them you know uh you can do all logging you want but
if no one's going to go back and look at the data it's not worth anything um the other thing about logs is they provide
the who and when they'll tell you what node talk to what node and at what time but they're not going to give you um
what actually transpired between those two connections so they don't tell you the what and what you need for the what
um is a pack is usually packet sniffer something to go out and look at that traffic I tried to get a picture of a
network sniffer I did a search on on the internet and um this is what I
found that's that's that's not the best sniffing picture but yeah so what you need sniffers for
is that you need sniffers to help you really see what's on your network they let you look at the zeros and ones um uh
intrusion detection systems Network intrusion detection systems really um help you do some pre-processing they give you some filtering to help you kind
of look at on specific information um switch to environments can be a challenge at times um instead
of a hub where you have a nice flat Network where you can see all the traffic you know with a switched environment you're going to have a lot of Point topoint links so you have to do
a little um design up front to determine where you can put your sniffers in in a
switched environment a lot of the new technology uh there's monitoring ports or supervisor ports right on the switch
so it's not as much of an issue um and these days a lot of the the tools are all being Consolidated so the
information is typically there anyway there's a picture of some raw output um
I got this slide from from Ron Gula I don't know if he's here or not but tell I gave him this props uh so this is just

through lots of packets you want to be able to look at them the same way over and over again so you get your consistent results and um tools and and
and systems really help you do that another tip is to filter and focus
um up front if you can do that for example if you know you're going to be looking at email traffic and you can

you're going to start seeing evidence um preservation being built right into the tools things like chain of custody

being able to store and retrieve large amounts of data um quickly um data mining is another big Trend
where you're able to um look for different events through um data mining algorithm techniques like like
clustering so you can kind of get a new new view of event information um correlating events being
able to look at individual events um across your network and then compile them into one source to get a a new look
or a different type of um event um from from the disparate from the disparate
nodes um event interpretation you're going to see a lot more of the ability to program um what you want your tools
to look for and being able to let you know that um this is based on a couple
different uh simultaneous events it's going to generate what you looking for in terms of a new
event passive monitoring you're going to see more tools being more passive on your network
a lot of people don't do a lot of monitoring now or auditing because it induces a load on your network or the systems um these are going to become
more more passive so it's not going to induce those loads um data exchange is important being able to look at
information from multiple sources um and being able to compile them together so there's no no loss and then some
artificial intelligence based on top to help predict um events and also to interpret some type of
intent um here's some examples of of some tools and some vendors
um again I mentioned counterpain before they're one of the um man security providers out there um there's another

monitor open open sources for new vulnerabilities or new events um they um
what they do is they they'll keep a profile of what your environment looks like anytime something new in the in the
in the world that may affect your environment happens they'll let you know um and then server vault is another

to some pretty Advanced networking monitoring techniques um Network appliances are another big Trend um and netf fox I

tr.com is our sponsor here um I think they're upstairs still probably get some
information from them if you're interested I'm just going to finish up with a couple tips
um the first one is just do it one step at a time I know you're all really jazzed up now to go out and do some
audit monitoring on your network um to run out there and do it all but really what you want to do is kind of design
find something up front then implement it and phase it in one step at a time um automation is your big friend it's going
to help you do things consistently um storage make sure you have enough storage again you can
collect a lot of information real fast so you need to be able to have enough storage to hold it all and then
sometimes that data that you're storing may be sensitive so you need to uh take that to consideration what you're
storing um and if you are going to do this it's really helpful if you can measure what you're doing to help win
